citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The veterinary teaching protocols (TD11-2020-11-goat, TD11-2020-12-horse, TD11-2020-13-cow) that cover the teaching
herds and training labs for the training of the third and fourth year veterinary students were approved by the IACUC on
2/8/2021. The facility currently houses animals of all three species and some were used in teaching labs in February 2024
after the protocol expiration date of 2/1/2024. The complete review of activities (protocols) is important to maintain
compliance and to allow the IACUC to ensure that the animal activities meet the AWA regulations. The IACUC shall
conduct complete reviews of activities covered at appropriate intervals as determined by the IACUC, but not less than
every 3 years. Correct prior to 5/31/24 and prior to using any animals in future training labs.

The fencing of one enclosure behind the vet school barn (the enclosure in the corner of two streets/drives) housing one
horse used for veterinary teaching needs repairs. An approximately two foot section of the bottom of the stainless steel
link fence adjacent to a corner has been damaged and is no longer attached to the bottom bar of the fencing. The fencing
is loose and has some sharp points. Another side of the same enclosure that forms the separation between two
enclosures (the one adjacent to the shelter structure) consists of sections of metal barred gates. These sections are
leaning at an approximately 30 degree angle. A tied rope is the only fastening holding the leaning section to an upright
secured end section. Damaged metal fencing and fencing not securely fastened can lead to injures of the horses housed
in the enclosures. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect
the animals from injury. Correct by May 2, 2024.

An outdoor enclosure housing a cow behind the large animal teaching hospital does not provide shelter from the
elements. It lacks natural or man-made shelter to protect the animal from inclement weather. There is a small tree in the
enclosure but at this time of the year it is not providing shelter. Inadequate protection from the elements can lead to
discomfort and potential distress for the animals housed within. Correct by ensuring adequate shelter to protect the cattle
from any adverse weather conditions. Correct by April 4, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Attending Veterinarian.
Additional Inspectors:
SUSANNE BRUNKHORST, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.31(d)(5) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
The veterinary teaching protocols (TD11-2020-11-goat, TD11-2020-12-horse, TD11-2020-13-cow) that cover the teaching 
herds and training labs for the training of the third and fourth year veterinary students were approved by the IACUC on 
2/8/2021. The facility currently houses animals of all three species and some were used in teaching labs in February 2024 
after the protocol expiration date of 2/1/2024. The complete review of activities (protocols) is important to maintain 
compliance and to allow the IACUC to ensure that the animal activities meet the AWA regulations. The IACUC shall 
conduct complete reviews of activities covered at appropriate intervals as determined by the IACUC, but not less than 
every 3 years. Correct prior to 5/31/24 and prior to using any animals in future training labs. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The fencing of one enclosure behind the vet school barn (the enclosure in the corner of two streets/drives) housing one 
horse used for veterinary teaching needs repairs. An approximately two foot section of the bottom of the stainless steel 
link fence adjacent to a corner has been damaged and is no longer attached to the bottom bar of the fencing. The fencing 
is loose and has some sharp points. Another side of the same enclosure that forms the separation between two 
enclosures (the one adjacent to the shelter structure) consists of sections of metal barred gates. These sections are 
leaning at an approximately 30 degree angle. A tied rope is the only fastening holding the leaning section to an upright 
secured end section. Damaged metal fencing and fencing not securely fastened can lead to injures of the horses housed 
in the enclosures. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect 
the animals from injury. Correct by May 2, 2024. 
3.127(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
An outdoor enclosure housing a cow behind the large animal teaching hospital does not provide shelter from the 
elements. It lacks natural or man-made shelter to protect the animal from inclement weather. There is a small tree in the 
enclosure but at this time of the year it is not providing shelter. Inadequate protection from the elements can lead to 
discomfort and potential distress for the animals housed within. Correct by ensuring adequate shelter to protect the cattle 
from any adverse weather conditions. Correct by April 4, 2024.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Attending Veterinarian. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
SUSANNE BRUNKHORST, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
